title-group.article-title: Generating string field theory solutions with matter operators from KBc algebra

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The KBc algebra is a subalgebra that has been used to construct classical solutions in Witten’s open string field theory, such as the tachyon vacuum solution. The main purpose of this paper is to give various operator sets that satisfy the KBc algebra. In addition, since those sets can contain matter operators arbitrarily, we can reproduce the solution of Kiermaier, Okawa, and Soler, and that of Erler and Maccaferri. Starting with a single D-brane solution on the tachyon vacuum, we replace the original KBc in it with an appropriate set to generate each of the above solutions. Thus, it is expected that the KBc algebra, combined with the single D-brane solution, leads to a more unified description of classical solutions.

institution-wrap.institution: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In Witten’s SFT, the background is defined through a first-quantized string theory which is described by a world-sheet conformal field theory (CFT), and the string field Ψ is a composite operator of the reference CFT. On the other hand, other backgrounds are realized by classical field configurations, solutions of the EOM, Q B Ψ + Ψ 2 = 0, where Q B is the Becchi–Rouet–Stora–Tyutin (BRST) operator of the reference CFT.

Since a bosonic string theory is unstable, any D-brane system will decay to the tachyon vacuum [ 2 , 3 ], regardless of what CFT we choose at the beginning. Thus, this condensation phenomenon must be characterized without any specific information of the reference CFT. In fact, the tachyon vacuum solution found in Refs. [ 4 , 5 ] can be described by the so-called KBc algebra [ 6 ], which is a universal subalgebra in the sense that any CFT possesses it. This universality of the KBc algebra guarantees that any D-brane system falls into the tachyon vacuum.

However, in order to establish the background independence explicitly, any background should be expressed by a solution of the EOM on the reference D-brane system. Since a background is determined by a world-sheet CFT, the problem we would like to solve is whether we can find a solution that corresponds to a given CFT. In particular, if we consider a one-parameter family of CFTs which includes the reference CFT, can we interpret it as a one-parameter family of SFT solutions? This problem has been addressed not only with the KBc algebra, but also with matter operators of the reference CFT.

One type of such one-parameter modifications is the marginal deformation , which keeps the conformal invariance of the reference CFT. The marginal deformation means adding to the CFT a boundary term which is characterized by a matter primary operator having weight 1. There have been many attempts to find solutions which correspond to marginally deformed CFTs [ 7–16 ]. Among those attempts, the solution of Kiermaier, Okawa, and Soler (KOS) [ 16 ] is known as a successful analytical solution, where the boundary condition changing operators (bcc operators) were introduced. Since marginal deformations add boundary terms, their effects are regarded as changes of boundary conditions; the bcc operators play the role of changing a boundary condition to another. The KOS solution is described by the bcc operators and the KBc algebra. Though valid only when the matter operators are regular,
1
it was generalized to non-regular cases by Erler and Maccaferri [ 17 , 18 ]. However, some questions, like how to explicitly find unknown bcc operators, still remain, even though their approach has advanced our understanding of the background structure.

In this paper we revisit the KBc algebra to deepen our understanding further. In Ref. [ 19 ], we found operator sets which consist of the original K, B , and c and satisfy the algebraic relations of the KBc algebra. We call these operator sets representations of the KBc algebra. Extending the previous method, we find in this paper a larger family of representations, which can arbitrarily contain matter operators. In addition, we can map the representations to the KBc algebra on the tachyon vacuum. By using this, we explicitly show that each of the KOS and Erler–Maccaferri solutions is reproduced by a specific representation of the KBc algebra. Although our work is mostly devoted to finding what kind of representation gives each solution, we will also discuss a potential ability of our framework to connect the KBc algebras in different CFTs. This is expected to lead to a deeper understanding of the whole background structure.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sect. 2 we introduce various representations of the KBc algebra with matter operators, both on a single D-brane solution and on the tachyon vacuum. Then, in Sect. 3 , we apply the latter to construct the KOS and Erler–Maccaferri solutions. In Sect. 4 we give a summary and discuss how to find unknown physically meaningful solutions by using our framework. Appendices A and B present the technical details used in the text. We discuss representations of the extended algebra including matter operators in Appendix C .

sec.title: Representations of the KBc algebra
sec.p: In this section we introduce representations of the KBc algebra containing arbitrary numbers of matter operators. We first give representations on a single D-brane, and next on the tachyon vacuum. The latter representations are used in Sect. 3 , and hence play a key role in this paper. For other attempts to consider representations of the KBc algebra, see Refs. [ 20–24 ].

sec.title: Representations on a single D-brane
sec.p:
Here we consider the world-sheet CFT which describes a single D-brane. As is well known, the KBc algebra is a subalgebra consisting of three operators K, B , and c in the CFT that satisfy the following relations [ 6 ]:
(1)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} [K,B]=0,\qquad \lbrace B,c\rbrace =1,\qquad B^2=0,\qquad c^2=0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(2)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}K = 0,\qquad Q_\mathrm{B}B = K,\qquad Q_\mathrm{B}c = cKc. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Originally, the K, B , and c appearing in the above relations were defined in the sliver frame as
(3)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} K = \int _{-i\infty }^{i\infty } \frac{{d}z}{2\pi }\, T(z),\qquad B = \int _{-i\infty }^{i\infty }\frac{{d}z}{2\pi }\, b(z),\qquad c = c(0). \end{eqnarray*} $$
We call the triad ( K, B, c ) in Eq. ( 3 ) the basic representation in this paper, and ( K, B, c ) always denotes the basic representation. In the following, we will find other triads which satisfy Eqs. ( 1 ) and ( 2 ) with the same BRST operator Q B on a single D-brane. We call them the representation of the KBc algebra (on a single D-brane) or KBc -representation for short.

Extending the idea of Ref. [ 19 ], we find that the triad ( K (ξ), B (ξ), c (ξ)) is also a representation of the KBc algebra, where
(4)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} K(\xi ) = Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1,\qquad B(\xi ) = \xi ^1,\qquad c(\xi ) = e^{-iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}c e^{iK\Xi ^2}\frac{B}{\Xi ^1}e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}c e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Let us explain the ingredients appearing in this expression. First, ξ = (ξ 1 , ξ 2 ) carries ghost number −1 and consists of ( K, B, c ) and matter operators.
2
Since matter operators commute with B and c , ξ can be expressed as
(5)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi = (\xi ^1,\xi ^2) = B(\Xi ^1,\Xi ^2) = (\Xi ^1,\Xi ^2)B, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with Ξ 1,2 consisting of K and matter operators. Note that K Ξ 2 = Ξ 2 K does not hold in general, and that the triad in Eq. ( 4 ) is real if Ξ 1,2 is real.
3
Of course, not all KBc -representations can be expressed as in Eq. ( 4 ). A more general form of KBc -representation is given in Appendix A .

Leaving the construction of Eq. ( 4 ) to Appendix A , here let us just confirm that Eq. ( 4 ) satisfies Eq. ( 1 ) and ( 2 ). Nontrivial relations are { B (ξ), c (ξ)} = 1 and Q B c (ξ) = c (ξ) K (ξ) c (ξ). To show the former, we first note that
(6)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^{1,2} &=& B(K\Xi ^{1,2} - BQ_\mathrm{B}\Xi ^{1,2}) = BK\Xi ^{1,2} = K\Xi ^{1,2} B,\nonumber \\ (Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^{1,2}) B &=& \Xi ^{1,2}KB = B\Xi ^{1,2}K. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Then we find that
(7)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B(\xi )c(\xi ) &=& \Xi ^1 B e^{-iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}c e^{iK\Xi ^2}\frac{B}{\Xi ^1}e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}c e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2} = \Xi ^1 e^{-iK\Xi ^2}BcB e^{iK\Xi ^2}\frac{1}{\Xi ^1}e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}c e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}\nonumber \\ &=&\Xi ^1 e^{-iK\Xi ^2}Be^{iK\Xi ^2}\frac{1}{\Xi ^1}e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}c e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2} =e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}Bc e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}=e^{-iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}Bc e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and similarly,
(8)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} c(\xi )B(\xi ) = e^{-iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}cB e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Therefore, { B (ξ), c (ξ)} = 1 holds due to { B, c } = 1.

Next, to show that Q B c (ξ) = c (ξ) K (ξ) c (ξ), we rewrite the right-hand side as
(9)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} c(\xi )K(\xi )c(\xi ) &=& -Q_\mathrm{B}(c(\xi )B(\xi )c(\xi )) + (Q_\mathrm{B}c(\xi ))B(\xi )c(\xi ) + c(\xi )B(\xi )Q_\mathrm{B}c(\xi ).\nonumber \\ &=&Q_\mathrm{B}c(\xi ) - (Q_\mathrm{B}c(\xi ))c(\xi )B(\xi ) - B(\xi )c(\xi ) Q_\mathrm{B}c(\xi ), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have used { B (ξ), c (ξ)} = 1, which we have just proven, and in particular that c (ξ) B (ξ) c (ξ) = c (ξ). Since we can directly confirm from Eq. ( 4 ) that Q B c (ξ) is written as
(10)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}c(\xi ) = e^{-iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}c\bigl [\quad \cdots \quad \bigr ]ce^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
we see that ( Q B c (ξ)) c (ξ) = c (ξ) Q B c (ξ) = 0, and hence that Q B c (ξ) = c (ξ) K (ξ) c (ξ) holds.

Note that Eq. ( 4 ) does not in general respect relations which are not in Eqs. ( 1 ) and ( 2 ) but are satisfied by the basic representation; for example, cKcKc = 0, which follows from [ c, K ] = ∂ c . An example is ξ = B (1 + ϵ K , 0) with ϵ infinitesimal and real. For this ξ, one can show that c (ξ) K (ξ) c (ξ) K (ξ) c (ξ) = ϵ cKcK 2 c + O (ϵ 2 ) ≠ 0.

sec.title: Representations on the tachyon vacuum
sec.p:
In the previous subsection we introduced the KBc -representations in Eq. ( 4 ) on a D-brane. As we know that the tachyon vacuum is the most basic background, it seems useful to find various representations of the KBc algebra in its corresponding CFT with a trivial BRST cohomology. In this case, Q B in the KBc algebra is replaced by Q tv ≔ Q B + [Ψ 0 , ·},
4
where Ψ 0 is the tachyon vacuum solution; we call this the KBc tv algebra.

We adopt the simple solution [ 5 ] as the tachyon vacuum solution:
(11)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi _0 = UQ_\mathrm{B} U^{-1} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}c(1+K)Bc\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(12)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} U = \left(\sqrt{1+K}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}Bc\right)\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(13)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} U^\ddagger = U^{-1} = \left(\sqrt{K} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}Bc\right)\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The BRST operator Q tv of the KBc tv algebra is defined by this Ψ 0 . Since we have
(14)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (UX U^{-1})(UY U^{-1}) = UXY U^{-1},\qquad Q_\mathrm{tv}(UX U^{-1}) = U(Q_\mathrm{B}X) U^{-1}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
for any X and Y , sandwiching Eq. ( 4 ) between U and U −1 directly gives KBc tv -representations,
(15)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= U(Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1) U^{-1} ,\qquad B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= U\xi ^1 U^{-1} ,\qquad \nonumber \\ &&c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= Ue^{-iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}c e^{iK\Xi ^2}\frac{B}{\Xi ^1}e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}c e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2} U^{-1}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Namely, this triad satisfies
(16)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} [K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv},B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}]=0,\qquad \lbrace B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv},c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}\rbrace =1,\qquad B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}^2=0,\qquad c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}^2=0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(17)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{tv}K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= 0,\qquad Q_\mathrm{tv}B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv},\qquad Q_\mathrm{tv}c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
In the following, we define X tv for any X as
5
(18)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} X_\mathrm{tv}:= U X U^{-1}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Using this notation and Eq. ( 14 ), we can rewrite Eq. ( 15 ) as
(19)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= Q_\mathrm{tv}\xi ^1_\mathrm{tv},\quad B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= \xi ^1_\mathrm{tv},\quad c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}= e^{-iQ_\mathrm{tv}\xi ^2_\mathrm{tv}}c_\mathrm{tv}e^{iK_\mathrm{tv}\Xi ^2_\mathrm{tv}}\frac{B_\mathrm{tv}}{\Xi ^1_\mathrm{tv}}e^{-i\Xi ^2_\mathrm{tv}K_\mathrm{tv}}c_\mathrm{tv}e^{iQ_\mathrm{tv}\xi ^2_\mathrm{tv}}. \end{eqnarray*} $$

sec.title: Construction of classical solutions
sec.p:
In this section we explicitly show that KBc tv -representations reproduce the KOS and Erler–Maccaferri solutions. Hereafter, the string field Ψ represents the deviation from the tachyon vacuum, meaning that its EOM is given as
(20)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{tv}\Psi + \Psi ^2 = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
In Ref. [ 17 ], the single D-brane solution on the tachyon vacuum, Ψ = −Ψ 0 , is deformed by using bcc operators [ 16 ] as
$-\Sigma \Psi _0\bar{\Sigma }$
, which was shown to give solutions corresponding to various backgrounds. Our strategy here is to deform −Ψ 0 by using KBc tv -representations to express backgrounds.

sec.title: Generating other solutions from a single D-brane solution
sec.p:
We first rewrite −Ψ 0 in terms of ( K tv , B tv , c tv ), which is obtained by applying Eq. ( 18 ) to the basic representation ( K, B, c ). Noting that
(21)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} U_\mathrm{tv}= UU U^{-1} = U, \end{eqnarray*} $$
we can rewrite −Ψ 0 as
(22)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} - \Psi _0 = -UQ_\mathrm{B} U^{-1} &=& U^{-1}U(Q_\mathrm{B}U)U^{-1} = U^{-1}Q_\mathrm{tv}(UUU^{-1})= U^{-1}_\mathrm{tv}Q_\mathrm{tv}U_\mathrm{tv}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have also used Eq. ( 14 ) at the third equality. By using Eq. ( 14 ) again, we see from Eqs. ( 12 ) and ( 13 ) that
(23)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} U &=& U_\mathrm{tv}= \left(\sqrt{1+K_\mathrm{tv}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K_\mathrm{tv}}}B_\mathrm{tv}c_\mathrm{tv}\right)\frac{1}{\sqrt{K_\mathrm{tv}}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(24)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} U^{-1} &=&U^{-1}_\mathrm{tv}= \left(\sqrt{K_\mathrm{tv}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{K_\mathrm{tv}}}B_\mathrm{tv}c_\mathrm{tv}\right)\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K_\mathrm{tv}}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
and hence we can regard −Ψ 0 as a string field expressed completely by ( K tv , B tv , c tv ):
(25)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} -\Psi _0 =U^{-1}_\mathrm{tv}Q_\mathrm{tv}U_\mathrm{tv}=: \Psi _1(K_\mathrm{tv},B_\mathrm{tv},c_\mathrm{tv}). \end{eqnarray*} $$

Since we only need the KBc tv algebra to show that Eq. ( 25 ) is a solution to the EOM in Eq. ( 20 ), the string field Ψ 1 ( K (ξ) tv , B (ξ) tv , c (ξ) tv ) is also a solution. Explicitly, we have
(26)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi _1(K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv},B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv},c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv})= \left[U_\mathrm{tv}^{-1}Q_\mathrm{tv}U_\mathrm{tv}\right]_\xi = -\left[\frac{1}{\sqrt{K_\mathrm{tv}}}c_\mathrm{tv}B_\mathrm{tv}\frac{K_\mathrm{tv}^2}{1+K_\mathrm{tv}}c_\mathrm{tv}\frac{1}{\sqrt{K_\mathrm{tv}}}\right]_\xi , \end{eqnarray*} $$
where [⋅⋅⋅] ξ means that ( K tv , B tv , c tv ) inside the bracket is replaced by ( K (ξ) tv , B (ξ) tv , c (ξ) tv ). If we choose ξ real, the triad ( K (ξ) tv , B (ξ) tv , c (ξ) tv ) is real, and hence the solution in Eq. ( 26 ) is. In the rest of this section we show that Eq. ( 26 ) reproduces the KOS and Erler–Maccaferri solutions by choosing suitable real ξs.

sec.title: Reproducing the KOS solution for marginal deformation
sec.p:
The KOS solution [ 16 ] describes a marginal deformation of the CFT characterized by a regular matter primary operator V with weight 1, where “regular” means that cV has a vanishing self-OPE. They introduced the bcc operators σ and
$\bar{\sigma }$
, which are matter primary operators of weight 0 and are related to V through
(27)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} V = -\sigma \partial \bar{\sigma },\qquad e^{-\alpha (K+V)} = \sigma e^{-\alpha K} \bar{\sigma }. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The following is also an important relation:
(28)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \sigma \bar{\sigma }= \bar{\sigma }\sigma = 1. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The solution is given as
(29)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi _\mathrm{KOS} = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}c(1+K)\sigma \frac{B}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }(1+K)c\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
which satisfies Eq. ( 20 ).

Our problem is to find ξ such that
(30)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} [\Psi _1(K_\mathrm{tv},B_\mathrm{tv},c_\mathrm{tv})]_\xi = \Psi _\mathrm{KOS}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Multiplied by U −1 and U , this condition reads
(31)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \frac{1}{\sqrt{K(\xi )}}c(\xi )\frac{K(\xi )^2}{1 + K(\xi )}B(\xi )c(\xi )\frac{1}{\sqrt{K(\xi )}} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}cK\sigma \frac{B}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }Kc\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}~ (=U^{-1}\Psi _\mathrm{KOS}U), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have used Eq. ( 26 ) and that U −1 [ X tv ] ξ U is equal to X with ( K, B, c ) in it replaced by ( K (ξ), B (ξ), c (ξ)).

By considering B (31) B , we obtain a necessary condition for Ξ 1 :
(32)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B\frac{1}{\sqrt{K\Xi ^1}}\frac{1}{\Xi ^1}\frac{(\Xi ^1K)^2}{1+\Xi ^1 K}\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}} = B\sqrt{K}\sigma \frac{1}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }\sqrt{K}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
In deriving the left-hand side, we have used Eq. ( 6 ) and B = B (ξ)/Ξ 1 . Since B commutes with all the other operators appearing in Eq. ( 32 ), we can remove B from it. Using
$\sqrt{K\Xi ^1} = K\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}K^{-1}$
, Eq. ( 32 ) with B removed is rewritten as
(33)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} K\frac{1}{1 + \Xi ^1 K} = \sqrt{K}\sigma \frac{1 }{1 + K}\bar{\sigma }\sqrt{K}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
which determines Ξ 1 :
(34)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Xi ^1 = 1+\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}\left[\left(\sigma \frac{1}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }\right)^{-1} -1-K\right]\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}} = 1 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}V\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Here we have used Eq. ( 28 ) and
$\sigma K \bar{\sigma }= K+V$
, the latter of which follows from the α-derivation of the second equation in Eq. ( 27 ). This Ξ 1 is real since we are taking a real V (hence
$\sigma ^\ddagger = \bar{\sigma }$
).

Next, let us determine Ξ 2 . For this purpose, we multiply Eq. ( 31 ) by B only from the left side to get a necessary condition for Ξ 2 :
(35)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \sqrt{K}\sigma \frac{1}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }\sqrt{K}\left[ \sqrt{\Xi ^1K}e^{-i\Xi ^2K}Bce^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1}} -\sqrt{K}Bc\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}\right]=0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have used Eq. ( 33 ). As proven in Appendix B , Ref. ( 31 ) actually follows from the condition that the quantity inside the bracket in Eq. ( 35 ) vanishes. Thus our task is to determine Ξ 2 from
(36)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \sqrt{\Xi ^1K}e^{-i\Xi ^2K}Bc\, e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1}} =\sqrt{K}Bc\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}. \end{eqnarray*} $$

For this purpose, note first the following expression for the quantity on the left-hand side of Eq. ( 36 ) obtained by using the singular homotopy operator B / K and the formula in Eq. ( 6 ):
(37)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1}} &=&Q_\mathrm{B}\!\left(\frac{B}{K}e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1}}\right) =Q_\mathrm{B}\!\left(\frac{B}{K}e^{iK\Xi ^2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{K\Xi ^1}}\right) =Q_\mathrm{B}\!\left(\frac{B}{\sqrt{K}}F^{-1}\frac{1}{K}\right), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have defined F by
(38)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} F:= \sqrt{\Xi ^1K}e^{-i\Xi ^2K}\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}.\qquad \end{eqnarray*} $$
Using Eq. ( 37 ), the left-hand side of Eq. ( 36 ) is rewritten as
(39)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \sqrt{\Xi ^1K}e^{-i\Xi ^2K}Bc\, e^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1}} &=&F\sqrt{K}Bc\, Q_\mathrm{B}\!\left(\frac{B}{\sqrt{K}}F^{-1}\frac{1}{K}\right)\nonumber \\ &=&F\sqrt{K}Bc\sqrt{K}F^{-1}\frac{1}{K}+B(Q_\mathrm{B}F)F^{-1}\frac{1}{K}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have used Q B F −1 = − F −1 ( Q B F ) F −1 at the second equality. Therefore, the condition in Eq. ( 36 ) for Ξ 2 (and hence for F ) is now reduced to
(40)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}F=[\sqrt{K}c\sqrt{K},F]. \end{eqnarray*} $$

Besides Eq. ( 40 ), we have to take into account that F is defined as a particular quantity in Eq. ( 38 ). Using (Ξ 1, 2 ) ‡ = Ξ 1, 2 (we will check (Ξ 2 ) ‡ = Ξ 2 below for the resultant Ξ 2 ), we obtain
(41)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} FF^\ddagger &=&\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}e^{-i \Xi ^2 K}\frac{1}{K}e^{iK\Xi ^2}\sqrt{K\Xi ^1} =\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}e^{-i \Xi ^2 K}e^{i\Xi ^2 K}\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}\frac{1}{K} =\Xi ^1 . \end{eqnarray*} $$
Let us take the simplest one as F satisfying Eq. ( 41 ):
(42)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} F=\sqrt{\Xi ^1} . \end{eqnarray*} $$
This F actually satisfies Eq. ( 40 ), as we shall show. From Eq. ( 34 ),
$\sqrt{\Xi ^1}$
is Taylor-expanded as
(43)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \sqrt{\Xi ^1} = \sum _{n=0}^\infty a_n\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}V\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}\right)^n = \frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}\sum _{n=0}^\infty a_n\left(V\frac{1}{K}\right)^n\sqrt{K}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
with numerical coefficients
a n
. From the fact that V is a matter primary operator of weight 1 and [ V, c ] = 0, we have
(44)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}V = [K,cV], \end{eqnarray*} $$
from which we also have
(45)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}\left(V\frac{1}{K}\right)= \left[Kc,V\frac{1}{K}\right]. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Since both Q B and the commutator follow the Leibniz rule, we have
(46)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}\left(V\frac{1}{K}\right)^n = \left[Kc,\left(V\frac{1}{K}\right)^n\right], \end{eqnarray*} $$
for all
$n \in \mathbb {N}$
. This implies that
$F=\sqrt{\Xi ^1}$
, given by the series in Eq. ( 43 ), satisfies Eq. ( 40 ). From Eq. ( 38 ), Ξ 2 corresponding to F of Eq. ( 42 ) is given in terms of Ξ 1 by
(47)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}}\sqrt{\Xi ^1}\sqrt{K}, \qquad \Xi ^2=i\ln \!\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}}\sqrt{\Xi ^1}\sqrt{K}\right) \frac{1}{K}. \end{eqnarray*} $$

Finally, let us confirm that (Ξ 2 ) ‡ = Ξ 2 for Ξ 2 of Eq. ( 47 ), which we used above. Note that
(48)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} e^{i(\Xi ^2)^\ddagger K}=\frac{1}{K}\, e^{iK(\Xi ^2)^\ddagger }K =\frac{1}{K}\left(\sqrt{K}\sqrt{\Xi ^1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{K\Xi ^1}}\right)K =\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}\sqrt{\Xi ^1}K\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Xi ^1 K}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have used the double conjugation of the first equation of Eq. ( 47 ) at the second equality. Multiplying this and Eq. ( 47 ) together, we obtain
(49)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} e^{-i\Xi ^2 K}\, e^{i(\Xi ^2)^\ddagger K} =1 . \end{eqnarray*} $$
This implies the reality of Ξ 2 .
6

In the above, we adopted Eq. ( 42 ) as F satisfying Eq. ( 41 ). We saw that this F satisfies the condition in Eq. ( 40 ) and that the corresponding Ξ 2 is real. However, we can take a more general F of the following form:
(50)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} F=\sqrt{\Xi ^1}\, e^{if(\Xi ^1)} , \end{eqnarray*} $$
where f (Ξ 1 ) is an arbitrary real function of Ξ 1 alone. This F satisfies Eq. ( 41 ), and, as seen by looking back on the above proofs of Eq. ( 40 ) and the reality of Ξ 2 for
$F=\sqrt{\Xi ^1}$
, we can easily see that the two properties hold also for F of Eq. ( 50 ). Note, in particular, that the series in Eq. ( 43 ) satisfies Eq. ( 40 ) for any coefficients
a n
. The same [Ψ 1 ( K tv , B tv , c tv )] ξ = Ψ KOS is reproduced for any f (Ξ 1 ).

Finally,
$\xi ^{1,2}_\mathrm{tv}$
for generating the KOS solution from the single D-brane solution in Eq. ( 25 ) on the tachyon vacuum are obtained from the Ξ 1,2 ( K, V ) we have determined above as
$\xi ^{1,2}_\mathrm{tv}=U\xi ^{1,2} U^{-1}=B_\mathrm{tv}\Xi ^{1,2}_\mathrm{tv}$
with
$\Xi _\mathrm{tv}^{1,2}=\Xi ^{1,2}(K_\mathrm{tv},V_\mathrm{tv})$
. Expressed in terms of the original ( K, B, c, V ),
$\xi ^{1,2}_\mathrm{tv}$
is given by
(51)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi ^{1,2}_\mathrm{tv}=UB\Xi ^{1,2} U^{-1}=B\sqrt{\frac{K}{1+K}}\Xi ^{1,2}\sqrt{\frac{K}{1+K}}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Note that, although Ξ 1 in Eq. ( 34 ) is singular at K = 0, this singularity is resolved in
$\xi ^1_\mathrm{tv}$
. This is the case also for
$\xi ^2_\mathrm{tv}$
obtained from Ξ 2 of Eq. ( 47 ). The singularities at K = 0 appearing in various places in our construction are artifacts of solving Eq. ( 31 ) for ξ 1,2 instead of the original Eq. ( 30 ) for
$\xi _\mathrm{tv}^{1,2}$
.

sec.title: Reproducing the Erler–Maccaferri solution
sec.p:
The Erler–Maccaferri solution [ 17 ] is a generalization of the KOS solution to the case where V is not necessarily regular. In this case, the boundary condition changing operators are modified to be accompanied by some matter operators, resulting in
$\sigma \bar{\sigma }= 1$
and the associativity
7
no longer holding, while
$\bar{\sigma }\sigma = 1$
is kept. Since Eq. ( 27 ) does not hold anymore, we have to express all equations in terms of σ and
$\bar{\sigma }$
, not using V . Despite those differences, the solution is still of the same form as Eq. ( 29 ):
(52)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Psi _\mathrm{EM} = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}c(1+K)\sigma \frac{B}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }(1+K)c\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+K}}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Our problem is to find ξ satisfying [Ψ 1 ( K tv , B tv , c tv )] ξ = Ψ EM .

Even in the present case, we can reach Eq. ( 33 ) with no obstacle, and hence we obtain
8
(53)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Xi ^1 =1+ \frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}\left[\left(\sigma \frac{1}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }\right)^{-1} -1-K\right]\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Following the previous process, we get Eq. ( 36 ) without any change. Therefore, we naively expect that Ξ 2 is again given by Eq. ( 47 ). The only difference from the KOS case is the process of showing that F of Eq. ( 42 ) satisfies Eq. ( 40 ), because we explicitly used V there.

Let us show that Eq. ( 40 ) is satisfied by
$F=\sqrt{\Xi ^1}$
here as well. We define
(54)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} S := \sigma \frac{1}{1 + K} \bar{\sigma },\qquad \qquad W := S^{-1} - (1+K). \end{eqnarray*} $$
Since Ξ 1 is written as
(55)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \Xi ^1 = 1 + \frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}W\frac{1}{\sqrt{K}}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
we have only to show that
(56)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}W = [K,cW],\qquad \quad [c,W]=0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
which correspond to Eq. ( 44 ) and [ c, V ] = 0. The latter relation can be shown as follows:
(57)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} S[c,W]S &=& Sc - Sc(1+K)S - cS + S(1+K)cS\nonumber \\ &=& \sigma \left[\frac{1}{1+K},c\right]\bar{\sigma }+ \sigma \frac{1}{1+K} \bar{\sigma }[1+K,c]\sigma \frac{1}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }\nonumber \\ &=& 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
In the last equality we have used that [1 + K, c ] = −∂ c is a ghost operator and commutes with σ. Next, let us consider the former relation in Eq. ( 56 ). We have
(58)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}W = -S^{-1}(Q_\mathrm{B}S)S^{-1} =-S^{-1}\left(c[1+K,\sigma ]\frac{1}{1+K}\bar{\sigma }+ \sigma \frac{1}{1+K}[1+K,\bar{\sigma }]c\right)S^{-1}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where we have used Q B σ = c [ K , σ] = c [1 + K , σ] and [ c , [1 + K , σ]] = 0, which follow from σ being a matter primary operator of weight 0 (
$\bar{\sigma }$
as well). As σ and
$\bar{\sigma }$
commute with c , we obtain the desired relation:
(59)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}W = -S^{-1}c(1+K) + (1+K)cS^{-1} = [K,cW]+[c,W](1+K) = [K,cW]. \end{eqnarray*} $$

As indicated in Ref. [ 17 ], Eq. ( 52 ) includes a solution which describes the change of the dimension of the D-brane or of the number of D-branes (see also Ref. [ 25 ] for the latter). In the latter case, σ and
$\bar{\sigma }$
have multi-components, but our construction here is still valid because ξ can contain arbitrary numbers of matter operators. Since Eq. ( 52 ) is expected to describe any backgrounds, the discussion here implies that any open string backgrounds can also be described by KBc tv -representations and Eq. ( 26 ), namely, [Ψ 1 ( K tv , B tv , c tv )] ξ .

sec.title: Discussions
sec.p: We have shown that there are various representations of KBc algebra which contain matter operators, both on a single D-brane and the tachyon vacuum. Each of the KOS and Erler–Maccaferri solutions was reproduced by modifying the single D-brane solution on the tachyon vacuum to the one in a proper representation. However, though our framework has the ability to determine the representation that reproduces a given solution, there is no guiding principle in our framework to find new physically meaningful solutions. Here we will discuss two possible directions for addressing this subject.

The first approach is to find the basic representation of other CFTs. In SFT, there exists a solution corresponding to any world-sheet CFT. In addition, given a CFT, there is always the basic representation, and hence Ψ 0 in Eq. ( 11 ) written by it gives the tachyon vacuum solution of the D-brane system described by the CFT. Since Ψ 0 consists of the basic representation, we can construct any backgrounds if we find the basic representation of each CFT in the language of the reference CFT. Our method has provided how to find various KBc triads, thus has opened a new way to realize this idea.

However, what we have found in this paper are representations on a single D-brane and on the tachyon vacuum, hence our method at a glance does not seem to connect KBc algebras of different CFTs. But, there is a clue. Recalling how we have obtained KBc tv -representations from KBc -representations, we can use a unitary transformation to go to representations in other CFTs. Let us consider a solution of the form
$[\Psi _1]_\xi = U(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}^{-1}Q_\mathrm{tv}U(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}$
, where U (ξ) tv denotes the unitary operator obtained from U tv in Eq. ( 23 ) by replacing ( K tv , …) with ( K (ξ) tv , …). Following the same logic as in Sect. 2.2 , a new triad,
(60)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} U(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}^{-1}(K(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}, B(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}, c(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}) U(\xi )_\mathrm{tv}, \end{eqnarray*} $$
forms a representation of the KBc algebra with its BRST operator given as Q ξ ≔ Q tv + [[Ψ 1 ] ξ , ·}. Starting with this triad, we can again generate a class of other representations, among which the basic representation of the KBc algebra in the CFT corresponding to [Ψ 1 ] ξ might exist. Thus, our method has a potential connection among different CFTs.

The other direction is to investigate the manifold-like structure explained in Ref. [ 19 ]. Witten’s open SFT has a similar structure to Chern–Simons theory, and several correspondences are known. For example, the star product corresponds to the wedge product, and the BRST operator to the exterior derivative. Though restricted to the KBc algebra, the interior product, Lie derivative, and Wilson line in SFT were introduced in Ref. [ 19 ]. The Lie derivative there can generate KBc -representations which do not include matter operators, so we defined the KBc manifold whose points are those representations.

As explained in Appendix A , the representations introduced in this paper are obtained by extending the previous construction in Ref. [ 19 ]. In Appendix A , we redefine the interior product and Lie derivative so that the resultant KBc -representations contain matter operators. However, for incorporating matter operators, we have to ignore some of their properties which were previously respected. For example, the interior product was nilpotent before, but now its second operation is not defined, because the operation of the interior product on matter operators is not defined (see Appendix A ).
9

The KBc manifold seems mathematically parallel to the ordinary manifold to some extent, hence it could be possible for it to have a more profound structure. In order to recover the lost properties, we have to impose further conditions on ξ, meaning that the representations we obtain are limited. If the KBc manifold is really a physical object, some proper restrictions may lead us to find a correct family of KBc -representations, which is expected to have a control over classical solutions in SFT.

ack.p: D.T. thanks Koji Hashimoto for valuable comments on his talk at “Strings and Fields 2021” in YITP, Kyoto. The work of D.T. was supported by Grant-in-Aid for JSPS Fellows No. 22J20722. J.Y. thanks Hiroshi Kunitomo for daily discussions on SFT.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: Open Access funding: SCOAP 3 .

app.title: Appendix A. Generating KBc -representations
app.p: We extend the method in Ref. [ 19 ] to the case where matter operators are included in KBc -representations. We first find an operation lowering the ghost number by 1, which is an analog of interior product in differential geometry. Second, we define an analog of the Lie derivative by using the interior product, which provides a differential equation to generate Eq. ( 4 ).

sec.title: A1. The interior product
sec.p:
We first construct as general an operation as possible that is linear and lowers the ghost number by 1, which we write as
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
. The subscript X is an as yet undetermined quantity which characterizes the operation. Let us start with the following ansatz:

list-item.p:
The operation of
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
on ( K, B, c ) is written by K, B, c and matter operators.

Acted by
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
, the both sides of each relation in Eq. ( 1 ) return the same result.

Against any product of the original ( K, B, c ),
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
acts according to the (anti-)Leibniz rule just as Q B does.

sec.p:
One might think it is a problem that we have not defined how
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
acts on matter operators. But, we will never need such operations. Here, we do not consider the “ KBc manifold” as we did in Ref. [ 19 ]. Instead, we only focus on finding KBc -representations including matter operators. If one would like to construct the manifold,
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
will be further restricted than what we will obtain here. The operation of
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
on matter operators is discussed in Appendix C .

The generic form of
$\mathcal {I}_{X}(K,B,c)$
is given as follows by ansatz (1):
(A1)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}_{X}K = iB f,\qquad \quad \mathcal {I}_{X}B = 0,\qquad \quad \mathcal {I}_{X}c = g +\sum _{n}h_L^{(n)}Bch_R^{(n)}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Here f, g , and
$h_{L,R}^{(n)}$
are general operators consisting of K and matter operators. We determine f, g , and
$h_{L,R}^{(n)}$
from ansatz (2) by using ansatz (3) for
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
acting on products. Among the relations in Eq. ( 1 ), [ K, B ] = 0 and B 2 = 0 do not impose any condition on those undetermined quantities; ansatz (2) is trivial for the two relations, because there is no quantity carrying a ghost number less than −1.

Next, let us consider ansatz (2) for c 2 = 0. The linearity of
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
gives
$\mathcal {I}_{X}0 = 0$
, and hence
$\mathcal {I}_{X}c^2$
must vanish. As a necessary condition,
$B\mathcal {I}_{X} c^2 = 0$
must also hold, which reads
(A2)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} gBc - Bc g- \sum _{n}h_L^{(n)}Bch_R^{(n)}=0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
From this,
$\mathcal {I}_{X}c$
is now written as
(A3)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}_{X}c = g+ [g,Bc] = \lbrace c,gB\rbrace . \end{eqnarray*} $$
By using the Jacobi identity for (anti-)commutators, one can straightforwardly show
$\mathcal {I}_{X}c^2 = 0$
from Eq. ( 3 ), meaning that Eq. ( A2 ) is sufficient. Under Eq. ( A3 ), let us show that
$\mathcal {I}_{X}\lbrace B,c\rbrace = \mathcal {I}_{X}1$
holds for any f and g . For the right-hand side, we have
$\mathcal {I}_{X}1 = 0$
because of the Leibniz rule. From Eq. ( A3 ), the left-hand side also vanishes as follows:
(A4)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}_{X}\lbrace B,c\rbrace = [\lbrace c,gB\rbrace ,B] = gBcB-BcgB = 0. \end{eqnarray*} $$

Note that both f and g are always multiplied by B in
$\mathcal {I}_{X}(K,B,c)$
. Thus, defining X 1 ≔ Bf = fB and X 2 ≔ Bg = gB , the final result is
(A5)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}_{X}K = iX^1,\qquad \quad \mathcal {I}_{X}B = 0,\qquad \quad \mathcal {I}_{X}c = \lbrace c,X^2\rbrace , \end{eqnarray*} $$
where X 1,2 consist of B, K , and matter operators, and its ghost number is −1.
10

sec.title: A2. Lie derivative
sec.p:
The definition of the Lie derivative here is
(A6)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pounds_{X} := -i\lbrace Q_\mathrm{B},\mathcal {I}_{X}\rbrace . \end{eqnarray*} $$
This is an analog of the ordinary Lie derivative given by the anti-commutator between the interior product and the exterior derivative. Note that
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
and £
X
are defined only for the original ( K, B, c ) and not for matter operators. Since the operation of
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
is not closed in the KBc algebra while Q B is, one may be afraid that our definition of
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
and £
X
is incomplete. However, this is not a problem for our purpose of constructing KBc -representations, as we shall see below. Here is the result of the action of £
X
on ( K, B, c ):
(A7)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pounds_{X}K = Q_\mathrm{B}X^1,\qquad \pounds_{X}B = X^1,\qquad \pounds_{X}c = -c(X^1 + i[X^2,K])c + i[c,Q_\mathrm{B}X^2]. \end{eqnarray*} $$

The key property of the Lie derivative is that it keeps the KBc algebra in the following sense. Let us consider a new triad,
(A8)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (\tilde{K},\tilde{B},\tilde{c}) := (K,B,c) + \epsilon \pounds_{X}(K,B,c), \end{eqnarray*} $$
with ϵ infinitesimal. Note that
(A9)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} [Q_\mathrm{B},\pounds_{X}] = 0 \end{eqnarray*} $$
holds due to
$Q_\mathrm{B}^2 = 0$
. Using this, we see that Eq. ( 2 ) holds for
$(\tilde{K},\tilde{B},\tilde{c})$
to O (ϵ); for example,
(A10)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}\tilde{B} = (1+\epsilon \pounds_{X})Q_\mathrm{B}B = (1 + \epsilon \pounds_{X})K = \tilde{K}. \end{eqnarray*} $$
In addition, one can easily confirm that £
X
follows the Leibniz rule, so Eq. ( 1 ) is satisfied by the new triad to O (ϵ); for example,
(A11)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \lbrace \tilde{B},\tilde{c}\rbrace = \lbrace B,c\rbrace + \epsilon \pounds_{X}\lbrace B,c\rbrace = 1 + \epsilon \pounds_{X}1 = 1. \end{eqnarray*} $$

sec.title: A3. Generating KBc -representations
sec.p: What we have learned above is that our Lie derivative can generate new KBc -representations which are infinitesimally changed from the basic representation. Thus, we expect that we obtain finitely changed KBc -representations if we successively apply the Lie derivative.

However, since we have not defined the action of the Lie derivative on X containing matter operators, such a naive successive operation of the Lie derivative is forbidden. In other words, we have to consider an appropriate Lie derivative on Eq. ( A8 ) and on the series of subsequent triads. To construct such a proper new derivative, let us consider the following new interior product:
(A12)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \tilde{\mathcal {I}}_{Y}\tilde{K} = iY^1,\qquad \quad \tilde{\mathcal {I}}_{Y}\tilde{B} = 0,\qquad \quad \tilde{\mathcal {I}}_{Y}\tilde{c} = \lbrace \tilde{c},Y^2\rbrace , \end{eqnarray*} $$
with Y 1,2 carrying ghost number −1. We again demand that
$\tilde{\mathcal {I}}_{Y}$
follows the (anti-)Leibniz rule, and define a new Lie derivative,
(A13)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \tilde{\pounds}_{Y} := -i\lbrace Q_\mathrm{B},\tilde{\mathcal {I}}_{Y}\rbrace . \end{eqnarray*} $$
From this definition and the (anti-)Leibniz rule of
$\tilde{\mathcal {I}}_{Y}$
, we find that
$\tilde{\pounds}_{Y}$
commutes with Q B and that
$\tilde{\pounds}_{Y}$
follows the Leibniz rule. This means that
(A14)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (1+\epsilon \tilde{\pounds}_{Y})(\tilde{K},\tilde{B},\tilde{c}) \end{eqnarray*} $$
is also a KBc -representation. The action of
$\tilde{\pounds}_{Y}$
on Eq. ( A8 ) is given by
(A15)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \tilde{\pounds}_{Y}\tilde{K} = Q_\mathrm{B}Y^1,\qquad \tilde{\pounds}_{Y}\tilde{B} = Y^1,\qquad \tilde{\pounds}_{Y}\tilde{c} = -\tilde{c}(Y^1 + i[Y^2,\tilde{K}])\tilde{c} + i[\tilde{c},Q_\mathrm{B}Y^2], \end{eqnarray*} $$
which is of the same form as Eq. ( A12 ).

Thus, we conclude that the triad (
K s
,
B s
,
c s
) with parameter s , which is determined through the following differential equations, is a KBc -representation:
(A16)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} &&\dot{K}_s = Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^1(s),\qquad \dot{B}_s = \dot{\xi }^1(s),\nonumber \\ &&\dot{c}_s = -c_s(\dot{\xi }^1(s) + i[\dot{\xi }^2(s),K_s])c_s + i[c_s,Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s)]. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Here, each of ξ 1,2 ( s ) is a function of s that consists of K, B , and matter operators, and the dot means s -derivative. The problem left for us is to solve Eq. ( A16 ). We put (ξ 1 (0), ξ 2 (0)) = ( B , 0) and adopt as the initial condition ( K 0 , B 0 , c 0 ) = ( K, B, c ).

The first two equations in Eq. ( A16 ) can be solved easily to give
(A17)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} K_s = Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1(s),\qquad \qquad B_s = \xi ^1(s). \end{eqnarray*} $$
Then, using
(A18)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} [\dot{\xi }^2(s),K_s] = [\dot{\xi }^2(s),Q_\mathrm{B}\xi ^1(s)] = [Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s),\xi ^1(s)] = [Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s),B_s], \end{eqnarray*} $$
we can rewrite the last equation in Eq. ( A16 ) as
(A19)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \dot{c}_s = -c_s(\dot{B}_s + i[Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s),B_s])c_s + i[c_s,Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s)]. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Since our construction of (
K s
,
B s
,
c s
) ensures that it must be a KBc -representation, we can use the KBc algebra among them in advance. Concretely, using {
B s
,
c s
} = 1, we can simplify the differential equation in Eq. ( 19 ) to
(A20)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \dot{c}_s = -c_s\dot{B}_s c_s + i[c_s(Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s))c_s,B_s]. \end{eqnarray*} $$

To solve this, we multiply it by
B s
from the left side to obtain
(A21)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \frac{{d}}{{d}s}(B_sc_s) = -i[Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s),B_sc_s]. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Here we have used
$B_s\dot{\xi }^{1,2}(s) = 0$
. This is solved as
(A22)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B_sc_s = E(s)^{-1}Bc E(s),\quad E(s) := \mathcal {S}\exp \left[i\int _0^s{d}s^{\prime }\, Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s^{\prime })\right], \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
$\mathcal {S}$
denotes the s -ordering which puts an operator with larger s to the right. Using {
B s
,
c s
} = 1 again, we also have
(A23)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} c_sB_s = E(s)^{-1}cBE(s). \end{eqnarray*} $$
By expressing ξ 1 ( s ) as ξ 1 ( s ) = B Ξ 1 ( s ), with Ξ 1 ( s ) consisting of K and matter operators (this is always possible), Eq. ( A22 ) reads
(A24)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} B c_s = \frac{1}{\Xi ^1(s)} E(s)^{-1}Bc E(s). \end{eqnarray*} $$
Multiplying this by Eq. (A23) × c from the left side and using
B s cB
=
B s
and
c s B s c s
=
c s
, we obtain
(A25)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} c_s = E(s)^{-1} cB E(s) c \frac{1}{\Xi ^1(s)}E(s)^{-1}Bc E(s). \end{eqnarray*} $$
Since the original differential equation for
c s
is a first-order ordinary differential equation, we conclude that Eq. ( A25 ) is the unique solution we have been looking for. Note that
c s
in Eq. ( A25 ) is not determined only by ξ( s ) but it in general depends on the whole of ξ 2 ( s ′ ) with 0 ≤ s ′ ≤ s .

If we choose as ξ( s ) a special one with
(A26)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \xi ^1(1) = \xi ^1,\qquad \quad \xi ^2(s) = s\xi ^2 \end{eqnarray*} $$
for given ξ 1,2 (ξ 1 ( s ) for 0 < s < 1 can be arbitrary), the triad ( K 1 , B 1 , c 1 ) turns out to be that of Eq. ( 4 ), the representation introduced in the text (we need Eq. ( 6 ) to obtain c (ξ) in Eq. ( 4 ) from c 1 ). One can also confirm directly that Eqs. ( 17 ) and ( A25 ) form a KBc -representation, by following the procedure shown in Sect. 2.1 .

app.title: Appendix C. Interior product and Lie derivative for matter operators
app.p:
We extend the action of the interior product and the Lie derivative to matter primary operators. For simplicity, we consider only one matter operator V with weight h . This V satisfies the following relations:
(C1)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} [B,V]=0,\qquad [c,V]=0, \end{eqnarray*} $$
(C2)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}V=c[K,V]+h[K,c]V. \end{eqnarray*} $$
We call Eqs. ( 1 ), ( 2 ), ( C1 ), and ( C2 ) together the KBcV algebra.

First, we extend the interior product
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
introduced in Appendix A to define
$\mathcal {I}_{X}V$
. In addition to the three ansatz in Appendix A , we impose the following two:

list-item.p:
$\mathcal {I}_{X}V$
is written by K, B, c and the matter operator V .

Acted by
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
, the both sides of each relation in Eq. ( C1 ) return the same result.

app.p:
The generic form of
$\mathcal {I}_{X}V$
is given by ansatz (4) as
(C3)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}_{X}V=BJ, \end{eqnarray*} $$
where J is a general operator written by K and V . We determine J through ansatz (5). Since
$\mathcal {I}_{X}[B,V]=0$
automatically holds, we just have to consider
$\mathcal {I}_{X}[c,V]=0$
. From Eqs. ( A5 ) and ( C5 ), we have
(C4)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}_{X}[c,V]=[\lbrace c,X^2\rbrace ,V]-\lbrace c,BJ\rbrace =\lbrace c,[X^2,V]-BJ\rbrace =0. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Therefore, choosing BJ = [ X 2 , V ],
$\mathcal {I}_{X}V$
is determined as
(C5)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \mathcal {I}_{X}V=[X^2,V]. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Note that, although
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
respects Eqs. ( 1 ) and ( C1 ), it does not necessarily keep other relations. In particular, the relation [ V , [ K, c ]] = 0 which follows from [ K, c ] = −∂ c is not kept by
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
,
$\mathcal {I}_{X}[V,[K,c]]\ne 0$
.

We can also define the Lie derivative for V as we did for ( K, B, c ) in Appendix A :
(C6)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pounds_{X}V&=&-i\lbrace Q_\mathrm{B},\mathcal {I}_{X}\rbrace V\nonumber \\ &=&-i[Q_\mathrm{B}X^2,V]+\lbrace X^1-i[K,X^2],cV\rbrace +(h-1)\lbrace X^1-i[K,X^2],c\rbrace V. \end{eqnarray*} $$
Then, let us solve the differential equation
(C7)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \dot{V_s}=-i[Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s) ,V_s]+ \lbrace \dot{\xi }^1(s)-i[K_s,\dot{\xi }^2(s)],c_sV_s\rbrace +(h-1)\lbrace \dot{\xi }^1(s)-i[K_s,\dot{\xi }^2(s)],c_s\rbrace V_s, \end{eqnarray*} $$
together with Eq. ( A16 ), by adopting V 0 = V as the initial condition. The resulting (
K s
,
B s
,
c s
,
V s
) constitute a KBcV -representation.

Solving the differential equation in Eq. ( C7 ) for an arbitrary h seems a difficult problem. However, we can solve it in the special case of h = 1, where V is a marginal operator. Therefore, we restrict the following arguments to h = 1. First, we consider
(C8)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \frac{{d}}{{d}s}(c_s V_s)=\pounds_{\dot{\xi }(s)}^{(s)}(c_s V_s)=-i\left\lbrace Q_\mathrm{B},\mathcal {I}_{\dot{\xi }(s)}^{(s)}\right\rbrace (c_s V_s), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where
$\pounds_{X}^{(s)}$
and
$\mathcal {I}_{X}^{(s)}$
are the Lie derivative and the interior product defined for (
K s
,
B s
,
c s
,
V s
). In particular,
$\mathcal {I}_{X}^{(s)}$
is defined by Eqs. ( A5 ) and ( C5 ) with ( K, B, c, V ) replaced by (
K s
,
B s
,
c s
,
V s
). Since Q B (
c s V s
) = 0 for h = 1, the differential equation in Eq. ( C8 ) is reduced to
(C9)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \frac{{d}}{{d}s}(c_s V_s)=-iQ_\mathrm{B}\mathcal {I}_{\dot{\xi }(s)}^{(s)}(c_sV_s)=-i[Q_\mathrm{B}\dot{\xi }^2(s),c_s V_s]. \end{eqnarray*} $$
The solution to Eq. ( C9 ) is given by
(C10)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} c_s V_s= E(s)^{-1}cVE(s), \end{eqnarray*} $$
where E ( s ) is defined in Eq. ( A22 ). Using this result,
V s
itself is obtained as
(C11)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} V_s =\lbrace B_s,c_s V_s\rbrace =\lbrace \xi ^1(s),c_s V_s\rbrace =\lbrace \xi ^1(s),E(s)^{-1}cVE(s)\rbrace . \end{eqnarray*} $$
If we choose ξ( s ) of Eq. ( A26 ), V (ξ) ≔ V 1 is given by
(C12)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} V(\xi )=\lbrace \xi ^1,e^{-iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}cVe^{iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}\rbrace . \end{eqnarray*} $$
This V (ξ), together with ( K (ξ), B (ξ), c (ξ)) of Eq. ( 4 ), constitutes a KBcV -representation. Starting with a solution containing matter operators, we can construct new solutions by using this representation.

However,
$\mathcal {I}_{X}$
and £
X
for matter operators have several problems due to the fact that
$\mathcal {I}_{X}[V,[K,c]]\ne 0$
. The first problem is that £
X
does not necessarily keep V real. For a real X , we have
(C13)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (\pounds_{X}(K,B,c))^\ddagger =\pounds_{X}(K,B,c), \end{eqnarray*} $$
and this property ensures that the triad ( K (ξ), B (ξ), c (ξ)) is real as long as ξ is real. On the other hand, for a real V , we have, from Eq. ( C6 ),
(C14)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} (\pounds_{X}V)^\ddagger =\pounds_{X}V + (h-1)\mathcal {I}_{X}[V,[K,c]]. \end{eqnarray*} $$
This implies that
V s
determined by Eq. ( C7 ) is no longer real unless h = 1.

Though this reality problem of
V s
is resolved for V with weight 1, there remains another problem that exists even in the case h = 1. This is the problem that the expression of £
X
V is not unique. This expression depends on the order of [ K, c ] and V in Eq. ( C2 ). If we rewrite Eq. ( C2 ) as
(C15)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} Q_\mathrm{B}V =c[K,V]+hV[K,c], \end{eqnarray*} $$
the corresponding
$\pounds_{X}V=-i\lbrace Q_\mathrm{B},\mathcal {I}_{X}\rbrace V$
is a different quantity from Eq. ( C6 ), but is given by
(C16)
$$\begin{eqnarray*} \pounds_{X}V=-i[Q_\mathrm{B}X^2,V]-c[X^1-i[K,X^2],V]+hV\lbrace X^1-i[K,X^2],c\rbrace . \end{eqnarray*} $$
Of course, if we choose one expression of £
X
V we obtain a family of KBcV -representations. However, the ordering problem and the resulting ambiguity of £
X
V may cause inconveniences, if one applies the algebraic tools we have developed here to other problems in SFT.

In this notation, Eq. ( 14 ) is written as X tv Y tv = ( XY ) tv and Q tv X tv = ( Q B X ) tv .

Ξ 2 has the arbitrariness of adding to it an integer multiple of 2π/ K since it appears only in the forms of
$e^{\pm iQ_\mathrm{B}\xi ^2}$
,
$e^{iK\Xi ^2}$
, and

in c (ξ) in Eq. ( 4 ). Therefore, Eq. ( 49 ) is the precise expression of the reality of Ξ 2 .

According to Ref. [ 17 ],
$\bar{\sigma }\sigma = 1$
but in general
$\sigma \bar{\sigma }= g \ne 1$
with g being a constant. Using this fact, we have
$S^{-1} = (\sigma (1+K)\bar{\sigma })/g$
for S defined in Eq. ( 54 ).
This fact does not affect the results in this paper. We discuss the operation of the interior product and the Lie derivative on matter operators in Appendix C .

X 1 and X 2 in this paper correspond to BX 1 and B ( X 2 / K ) in Ref. [ 19 ] (see Eq. (2.6) there), respectively. Recalling the correspondence between the form number in differential geometry and the ghost number in open SFT, which was indicated in Ref. [ 19 ], it is natural that X 1,2 , which we expect is an analog of the tangent vector, has ghost number −1.
